Setting up a Kinect on Linux in 2025

üìÖ 05 Jul 2025 ‚Ä¢ ‚è≤Ô∏è 5 mins ‚Ä¢ üá¨üáß • low-level

The Kinect is a 15 years old üë¥ virtual reality device developed by Microsoft for its Xbox 360 console. I recently gained an increasing interest in working with this device üìπ for some project. I was more preceisely looking for a cheap and reliable way to perform real time 3d tracking device. In this post, we will see how this device could be worth a try for developping more than a decade after its release. We will see various ways of developing with the original gaming device üéÆ on a Linux system and eventually run some libraries to get a full real time 3D pose estimation!

> The original Kinect for xbox 360, image from wikimedia.

Beyond the technical aspects that give the opportunty to learn, this review also brings into perspective concerns about the evolution of technologies, its complexity and the question of obsolescence.

Some background

The Kinect device was first presented at the E3 2009 (Project Natal) as a motion controller in response to Nintendo‚Äôs wii Remote and Sony‚Äôs PlayStation Move. The device can was presented a webcam and was not intended to be used with any othe physical device. It has a microphone, a set of motors and 2 cameras: a RGB camera and a InfraRed Depth camera.

One of the most noticeable aspect of the device is the capability to perform 3D pose tracking in realtime : an interesting feature in the gaming industry but alos in other areas such as healthcare, robotics, etc.. With 3D pose tracking, the user is indeed able to recover a coarse 3D (more or less detailed) skeleton of people‚Äôs body in the camera field.

> An example of 3D pose tracking, image from wikimedia.

The Kinect‚Äôs successors ü™¶

Despite the limited success of the first Kinect‚Äôs üí∏, Microsoft released a second version of its device together with the release of their Xbox One console in 2013. The new device, called Kinect 2 or Kinect One, was originally controversially bundled with the new console to favor its adoption. As we may understand, criticisms were notably raised for privacy concerns üîí. This resulted in an updated version of the console that was then sold alone with its Kinect port being removed by Microsoft (An external power adapter was then provided with the device).

In parallel, Microsoft also released alternative versions of the two controllers dedicated to programmers and compute applications: the Kinect for Windows and Kinect 2 for Windows. These two additional devices had their hardware slightly modified for their release on computers. Theses releases were acommpanied by two respective Software Development Kits (and drivers), allowing developpers to write their own applications for the Kinects. Of course, at the time we were not ready to see any effort from Microst to release Linux or Macos versions of the drivers and SDK‚Äôs ü§∑. Also important to note, these models were sold at a significantly higher price then their xbox counterparts, and they are particularly hard to find nowadays.

> On the left, the first Kinect for Windows (image from PC Perspective). On the right, the second Kinect for Windows (image from Stuff.tv).

Although Microsoft‚Äôs SDK had official support only for the Windows versions of the Kinects devices (1 and 2), it was realised that the two versions of the devices (Windows vs Xbox version) were extremely close, evene with SDK compatibility for the Kinect for Xbox versions. This fact may have driven the developers community to invest more efforts in using the device!

-> check OpenKinect SDK http://openkinect.org/wiki/Main_Page

In ‚Ä¶, Microsoft persisted with the Kinects by releasing a third model : the Azure Kinect. Unlike the others, this one was dedicated

Other options for 3d pose tracking

There exists several technologies capable of producing the same results:

  • Virtual Reality devices enable full body tracking, but VR devices remain particularly expensive

  • Motion capture technologies, used mostly in the cinema industry, allow for body tracking as well but they necessitates heavy hardware, additional body markers and more importantly they are not dedicated to real time applications

  • Deep learning now allows for pose estimation from RGB cameras thanks to Convolutional Neural Networks, even in real time but these full software based solutions would require high GPU compute capabilities to perform fast neural network inference

  • The remaing option is to rely on depth sensors devices (analogous to Kinect‚Äôs technology). Other Depth sensors exist but once again these are more expensive than the old Kinect one.

> The intel RealSense D435 device, another type of Depth camera. Image from wikimedia.

At the end, the Kinect solution for 3D real time pose tracking appears to be the most affordable one. Inedded, the device can still be found in second hand stores in 2025 and became relatively cheap due to its lack of use outside of the world of xbox 360 gaming.

However, there is one important point to consider before jumping into the setup. Such devices remain useable as soon as drivers and softwares remain available. This is far from being easy since hardware and software is evolving fast and since devices produced in the industry are mostly closed source and even safe-guarded!
